title: Can I plug headphones into an electric acoustic guitar, so nobody can hear me play? - Quora

response.answer_text: You can plug your headphones into your guitar, but you are right. No one will be able to hear you play. Not even you. The pick ups do not produce enough signal to drive even the little speakers in your headphones on their own. You will need at least a little bit of amplifier. Many regular amps have a headphone jack exactly for this purpose. It cuts off the main speaker when you use it. Or there are tiny little amps that plug into your guitar without a cable, which dont even have a speaker. They are made to produce just enough power to be a headphone amp. The one i have is powered by a couple of small batteries Of course if you are playing a hollow body, or an acoustic-electric, you will still make quite a bit of sound naturally. To be realy quiet, you will want a solid body guitar.

I’ve got a better idea, that I totally discovered by accident…..I bought a couple of them cheapie hearing aids on Amazon($20 bucks for 2, rechargeable!!!, NO BATTERIES!!!); for watching TV. One day I decided to find out what my acoustic/electric guitar sounded like unplugged, and using the hearing aid…….BABY, WHAT AN EXPERIENCE!!!,it amplifies the sound and puts it right in yer ear, and BEST PART??? You are playing TOTALLY un-amplified, the sound in your ear is GREAT, and you’re not disturbing anyone else!! PS, DON’T run the volume on the hearing aid too high, it can really hurt if it’s too high.

I have a Yamaha Silent Guitar Steel String Edition (SLG200S). I’m able to plug in a headphone directly into headphone socket (of the Guitar) and hear myself play. Without the headphone, I’m still able to hear myself play (with no background noise) but it’s just too quiet. I use Yousician with IRig 2. With the headphone out of iRig 2 connected using the audio cable to the Aux port and headphones plugged into the guitar’s headphone socket, I’m able to hear myself play with Yousician supplying the background. It’s just awesome and a must have if your family has had enough of your painful journey to become a rockstar ;)

Yes, you can, and no one will hear you play, including yourself. A headphones just contains speakers and you need an amp too. Some headphones have a build-in amp. But there also are tiny amps you can plug your guitar into. Some of these tiny amp you can plug directly into your guitar. Some tiny amps even have effects build in. You don’t need a lot of budget for these things. About 40 dollars, but you can go from 10–100.

You’re going to need a solid body guitar, not an electro-acoustic. Guitars won’t drive headphones, but with the right adapter, yes you can do this. Examples of ways to do it: amPlug 2 Guitar/Bass Headphone AmplifiersElectro-HarmonixiRig 2 - Guitar interface adapter for iPad, iPhone iPod touch, Android and Mac. and several other products from IK.Line 6 | Pocket POD and many other multi-effects units.

Yes, you can plug headphones into an electro-acoustic guitar. But people will still hear you, because you still have the acoustic part that you cannot mute unless you don’t play anything at all. You want a fully electric guitar or a “silent guitar” to use with headphones. You will also want a preamp that can drive headphones, if it is not built-in.

A hollow-bodied electric guitar will carry a bit, so your best bet for almost-silent practice is to get a solid-body electric. The simplest solution would be to run a cable from your electric guitar to a practice amplifier that has a headphone jack. I’ve played quite a bit on a solid-body electric that was unplugged. It’s musical enough, but someone sleeping in the next room will never notice it.

You can’t, but there are devices that you plug into that act like an amp for your headphones. You can also get a USB adapter that allows you to play through your computer. Many of them have a headphone jack in them (like the one from Behringer) so you can use either your computer, or keep it muted and just put it through the headphones. Those devices are pretty cheap - like $40 or so.

In addition to the other suggestions….. If you have an iPhone or ipad, the new ones come with “Garage band”. By using an adaptor, you can plug your guitar into the adaptor, plug the adaptor into your device, and either listen through earbuds or through the device’s speaker. GarageBand has a wide variety of effects and features so that you can compose and record your own stuff.

One reason, besides power (if you are plugging directly into the 1/4 jack on the instrument, electric or hybrid) is that the output is intended to drive a high impedance input, 10,000 Ohms or more- think of it as high pressure- you don’t need a lot of signal strength to work. Headphones are usually around 4 Ohms- the difference between the 1/4 jack and the headphones completely tanks the signal. The ear type headphones for cells may have a much higher impedance (less power for the cell to use) and might work- if you don’t mind awful sound. There are in-ear wired sets that are electrically like headphones, and sound like good headphones too.

Yes, but only with some guitars. I have a Yamaha SLG (silent guitar) and it works well with headphones or when fed to an amp. I own the classical version (SLG200NW) so I can’t say how well the steel string version imitates a true electric guitar. The only alternative I’m aware of is connecting through a practice amp and its headphone socket.

If you plugged headphones into an electric acoustic guitar everyone would still be able to hear you play. On a plus side (or negative, if you were intending to include yourself in the ‘nobody’) you would also be able to hear.

The output signal of the guitar is insufficient to drive the headphones. You can run the guitar output into a headphone pre-amp and plug the headphones into that. A simple 2 channel headphone pre-amp is quite inexpensive and can have other uses down the road.
